When Tony Blair's first cabinet met in 1997, anyone trying to guess which faces would still be there a decade later would probably not have picked out Alistair Darling's. Back then, the chief secretary to the treasury already felt like part of the political furniture. But for a veteran, he seemed a strangely anonymous figure - opaque to the point of unknown.

A blaze of glitzier New Labour stars have since fallen, yet Darling survived, accumulating five ministerial posts on a stainless ascent to the exchequer last year. His career had been distinguished by an almost freakish absence of failure. He has never lost an election, he joined the front bench after just 12 months in parliament, and 20 years later he has never left. Only two other members of that first cabinet, Gordon Brown and Jack Straw, are still in government with Darling today.

Yet he remains something of an enigma. What is the occupant of Number 11 really like? Few outside his inner circle would claim to know. "For most of my political life," Darling admits, "I've kept out of doing this kind of interview. You have to be quite careful - unless you're one of those people who's happy to give everything of themselves. And I, for one, am not."

In sunnier economic times, a chancellor might have been allowed the luxury of privacy. But people want to know if he is the man who can steer us out of trouble. After a stormy year of 10p tax rows, lost disks, the collapse of the housing market, rising prices and recession fears, rumours of his demotion are rumbling through Westminster. Darling gives no impression of believing them. But the mood is so febrile, it's even possible he won't be chancellor by the time this interview appears.

The last time we met, on a Question Time panel 10 years ago, he had been rigid with nerves - a rod of anxiety in a suit - so I was wondering how we'd get through two days together on a remote Scottish island. The croft on Lewis in the outer Hebrides where we're heading belongs to Darling, his mother and his sisters, and has been a family retreat all his life. It is the place where, he says, he is happiest. When he greets us at the gate looking tanned and rumpled, a bowl of homemade soup in one hand, the other pointing to eagles overhead, I scarcely recognise him.

We are welcomed like old friends by his wife, Maggie, a gregarious Scottish former journalist who cooks and makes tea and supper while Darling lights a fire. His dry, deadpan humour lends itself to his ironic take on the grumpy old man, which he plays with gruff good nature. Wendy Alexander, the former Scottish Labour leader, is "not likable at all"; Cherie Blair's memoirs were "awful", and as for the Dome - "well, thank God I didn't have to go there on millennium night". He can't abide this modern practice of kissing - people lurching at each other's faces - "when they've never even met!"

He reminds me of childhood friends' fathers who seemed fearsome until we got old enough to realise they were being funny. His press adviser, Catherine, another Scottish former journalist, teases him about his limited wardrobe and reluctance to spend money. He doesn't like having his picture taken either, grumbling, "It's like being at a wedding" - but allows the photographer to take all the time he wants without once objecting.

On the beach, the photographer asks him to look out to sea. He obediently gazes west across the Atlantic, murmuring, "I am looking at the sub-prime market." Even when he gets soaked by a wave on the beach, he doesn't complain. "Oh no, you didn't have your collar all scruffed up like that for the pictures, did you?" Maggie exclaims when we get back to the house. "But that's just what I look like," he says.

"Now Alistair," Catherine tells him firmly when eventually we sit down for the interview, "tell her everything. Make sure you tell her everything."

When his old friend handed over the keys to Number 11, Darling didn't expect the job to be easy. "Becoming chancellor is completely different from any other appointment. Completely different. Even when times are easy, it's important, because you're dealing with money, and money affects how everything works. When times are far from easy, it's even more difficult. And we knew the economy was going to slow down." But he hadn't the faintest inkling of the financial crisis about to unfold before him. "No, no one did. No one had any idea."

He can clearly recall the day last summer when alarm bells first began to sound. The chancellor was on holiday with his wife and their two teenage children in Majorca. "I remember I picked up the FT in the supermarket, as you do, and it had the European central bank starting to put money into the economy. I phoned the office to ask why they were doing quite so much. It didn't surprise me that money was going in - there was concern going around - but it was the sheer scale of it. I said, what about our institutions? This was when Northern Rock started to figure."

When news broke of the first run on a British bank in more than a century, Darling was back in Edinburgh. "I received a phone call and went straight down to London. From where I never returned. That was the last time I saw Edinburgh."

Even then, the gravity of the credit crunch was still not fully clear. "No one knew how serious it was yet." Then he received the second catastrophic phone call of last summer, from his private secretary - and this time the head of Her Majesty's Revenue & Customs was also on the line, with news of a major blunder.

"I just thought," Darling says, "this is a disaster. This is terrible. I said, We have to search the place from top to bottom. One of them said, We'll start Monday. I said, No, we start today. I phoned Gordon up. I said, We appear to have lost two disks containing the personal details of just about every family in the country. We knew it was bad." What did Brown say? "He said it was bad."

Darling's life, in his wife's words, has been "a crisis a week" ever since. The economic times we are facing "are arguably the worst they've been in 60 years," he says bluntly. "And I think it's going to be more profound and long-lasting than people thought."

In Edinburgh, Darling used to enjoy what would pass in Westminster for a healthy hinterland. He loves Leonard Cohen, and lists Midnight Express, Annie Hall and Local Hero as his favourite films. "There's got to be a life outside politics. It was nice to go to the pictures and go for a nice meal afterwards. One of the great pleasures was getting to Edinburgh and going out for a meal with friends who don't do politics."

But he has not been to the cinema in more than a year. His wife has moved down to Downing Street, and when they went for a meal with another couple recently, and tried to order a second bottle of wine, "the waiter came over and said 'too much wine'. In a loud voice. So we stuck to the one bottle for the entire meal." Another meal out with his press adviser was reported in the News Of The World as a decadent affront to struggling families. "It's just the way things are," he says, matter-of-factly. "It's understandable."

I wonder what it must be like for someone whose career had been hitherto blameless to find himself publicly upbraided by wine waiters. "Well, I think most people understand perfectly well that most of the problems they face are international. However, that doesn't help sell their house. I was at a filling station recently, and a chap said, 'I know it's to do with oil prices - but what are you going to do about it?' People think, Well, surely you can do something, you are responsible - so of course it reflects on me."

Is it painful to be blamed so personally?

"No, there's nothing more pathetic than people feeling sorry for themselves. So you get on with it, you just have to deal with it. There's lots of people who'd like to do my job. And no doubt," he adds, half under his breath, "actively trying to do it."

Ministers are seldom willing to discuss their own job prospects, so when I raise the rumours of an imminent reshuffle, I expect a formula along the lines of "that's up to the prime minister". But Darling can be surprisingly direct, and shakes his head impatiently.

"Frankly, if you had a reshuffle just now, I think the public would say, Who are they anyway? You name me a reshuffle that ever made a difference to a government, actually." Brown, he points out, had to make ministerial changes in January, following Peter Hain's resignation. "And you can't be chopping and changing people that often. I mean, undoubtedly at some stage before the end of the parliament he will want to do a reshuffle, but I'm not expecting one imminently. I do not think there will be a reshuffle."

Does he expect Labour to hang on to its seat at the forthcoming byelection? "Well, we'll give it our best shot. But we've got our work cut out. This coming 12 months will be the most difficult 12 months the Labour party has had in a generation, quite frankly. Both the general economic situation, and in terms of the politics. In the space of 10 months we've gone from a position where people generally felt we were doing OK to where we're certainly not doing OK. We've got to rediscover that zeal which won three elections, and that is a huge problem for us at the moment. People are pissed off with us.

"We really have to make our minds up; are we ready to try and persuade this country to support us for another term? Because the next 12 months are critical. It's still there to play for. But we've got a hell of a lot to do. We patently have not been able to get across what we are for, and what we are about."

Can Brown communicate it? "Yes, I do think he can. I do think he will." Then why hasn't he? "Er, well," Darling falters. "Well, it's always difficult, you know. You can always say, what could you have done better, and all the rest of it. But Gordon, in September, up to party conference, has got the opportunity to do that. And he will do that. It's absolutely imperative."

Darling is one of Brown's closest and oldest political friends. When his daughter phones during dinner, she is babysitting for the prime minister; his wife is friends with Sarah Brown. The orchestra of criticism has been upsetting - "We're grown-ups, but no one likes to read nasty things about their friends" - and he flatly refuses to blame Brown for anything. There will not, he insists, be a leadership challenge.

For Brown to repay his friend's loyalty by sacking him would be brutal - even Shakespearean. But then, politics can be like that. Darling is one of the most experienced politicians in the country. And yet, more than once, I find myself wondering how much of a political animal he really is.

Darling was born in 1953, the eldest of four in a middle-class family that was neither tribal, nor intellectual, nor even Labour. Both his grandfathers had been Liberals, his great-uncle a Tory MP in Edinburgh, and his father, a civil engineer, voted Conservative.

"We were an ordinary family. We talked about events, but we didn't sit around the table having intense discussions about what Marx thought." Not like the Milibands, then? "No," he agrees quickly. "Very different people. But we had a very clear sense of what was right and what was wrong. My father always thought Conservatism was about helping people less fortunate than you. My mother was very clear about what you did and didn't do, she was very clear about saying thank you and being courteous."

He was educated at Loretto, a rather traditional boarding school in Scotland. There was no teenage radicalism, and he would have been astonished, he says, if he'd known his future lay in politics. Studying law at Aberdeen, he stood for election in the student union, but not for a party. "I was just quite interested in getting things done." His manifesto favoured "strictly bread-and-butter issues, things like food prices in the student refectory". When he joined the Labour party in 1977, he never expected to be more than a member. "I was enjoying becoming a lawyer." He'd simply realised, he explains, that "if you want to make any changes, there's only one way you can do it, and that's by getting into a position where you can influence things. And the obvious thing to do seemed to be to join a party." Why Labour?

"Just... I suppose, overall, I thought the Tories were unfair. They were only for one side, and not for everyone. The Labour party just seemed to reflect my outlook on life - you know, that we were better working together - fairness, helping everyone to get on, rather than just a few. The Labour government in 1977 was in a terrible mess, and I was getting fed up looking at all these things on the television, and thinking, God, surely we can do better than that. I wanted to do things. But I was never really interested in the theory of achieving things, just the practicality of doing things."

One might say this has been Darling's great strength. The pragmatic clarity made him a highly effective minister, and probably explains why he was one of the few to maintain close relations with both Brown and Blair throughout their internecine rivalry. But it may well also be his weakness - for at times he seems almost too straightforward, even high-minded, for the low cunning of political warfare.

Earlier this month, on the Today programme, the chancellor chose not to deny a newspaper report of a proposal under consideration for a holiday for stamp duty. Property sales promptly seized up as buyers held off to wait for his decision, and furious estate agents accused him of destroying what was left of the market. "The news story didn't come from us," he protests, "we weren't the ones who leaked it. It had already appeared in other newspapers before, and at any other time I would just have ignored it. But understandably, I was asked about it." The option of lying and denying it didn't seem to occur to him - but then nor, he admits, had the consequences for the property market of his words.

If that was a schoolboy error, you might have thought Darling would want to put it right as quickly as he could, by issuing a definitive statement. "When I've got something to say about housing," he retorts stiffly, "then I need to deal with a whole range of things." If I was trying to sell my house right now, I would wish he'd hurry up. "Yes, all right, but if you're going to announce anything in the housing market, you don't do it in the middle of August. It's just a silly time to do it." Does he feel no sense of urgency? "I'll do it when I'm ready to do it."

When voters are complaining that Labour seems indifferent to their problems, such an own goal seems mystifying. Other ministers are currently exhorting Labour to "show" the voters it cares - and Darling rightly scoffs at this line. "I get very exasperated when people say we need to show people we are concerned. It's just the wrong approach. I think there's not a man, woman or child in this country who doesn't understand the problems people are facing. People are not particularly interested in public demonstrations of your 'understanding'. You just need to get on with it." Why he doesn't apply his own advice to stamp duty, and get on with it, is a mystery.

It is also a gift to the opposition. George Osborne has grown adept at pouncing on such opportunities - yet when I ask Darling why his shadow would make a bad chancellor, he pauses before replying, "I wouldn't personalise it. My criticism is not of him as an individual." But, I exclaim, Osborne is after your job! And he doesn't seem to mind personalising the fight.

"Why I think the Tories are bad is different from why I think Osborne would be a bad chancellor," Darling goes on. "I think my criticisms are of the Tory party rather than him." But his criticisms are oddly contradictory, for one minute he says, "the Tories haven't really changed. They may have packaged things differently, but fundamentally I think they are still very much focused on helping a few people, and not very bothered about most people." But then he says, "There are times when I listen to Cameron and I'm not sure what he does believe in. I don't say that in any nasty sense. I just don't have any sense of what, if he was prime minister, he would want to do."

When you are trailing by more than 20 points in the polls, it's probably time to start fighting dirty. Yet Darling continues, "I think you're right, George Osborne is a politician, and he's made an enormous amount of promises, but it's not clear how he would pay for them. Osborne knows what he's doing in terms of playing the political field. That's why I say he's a very good politician, because he takes his moment. But what's his long-term view of where the country needs to go? What is his vision for the future? What sort of country does he see Britain becoming in the next 20 to 30 years? I just don't know."

In the current climate, I'm not sure voters give a stuff about abstract visions for a generation away. But Darling does share most people's daily concerns - probably more than Osborne, the son of a titled millionaire, ever could. He does the family shopping in Tesco, and when I test him on the price of groceries he is spot-on. "Half a dozen eggs? That would be £1.20. I know they have cheaper ones, I saw them. But the ones my wife specifically wanted were £1.20."

If Darling lacks the pugnacity of a devious old Labour bruiser, he also struggles to compensate for it with a new Labour instinct for spin. "Throughout my life," he agrees, "I much prefer to be doing things than shouting about them." Of course, he adds, "part of politics is you do need to shout. Politics is the art of communication. If you can't communicate, then it doesn't matter if you're truly brilliant as a technocrat. There are lots of people who are very good, but they just can't communicate it." He doesn't say so, but I suspect this is a lesson he has learned most forcibly since Brown took charge.

What did he think, I ask, when he saw the photographs of the Browns and the Camerons on their holidays. "Well, it was the same reaction I used to have with the Blairs - thank God I don't have to do that." Didn't he notice any presentational issues?

"Well, they're just different people." he says. "I mean, it was probably an accurate representation of both of them. I didn't... Honestly, I just couldn't get excited about those pictures one way or the other. I mean, of course they're both posed. Cameron was as posed as they come!" But the trick, I suggest, is appearing relaxed even when posing. "Well, to me it looked posed," he retorts. "But I'm not going to be hypocritical about it when I've spent 15 minutes on a beach being photographed in a very unnatural posture."

Maybe, he reflects, "that's why I'm not a great politician. You know, I'm not very good at looking at pictures and subjecting them to the equivalent of textual analysis."

The funny thing is, on paper, Darling should be the perfect politician. He is exactly what the public always says it wants: decent, straightforward, unostentatious. The ideological intensity of Brown unnerves voters, and they didn't trust Blair's showmanship - but if Darling has vanity it seems invested entirely in doing the job well. He doesn't call himself a socialist - "There's nothing wrong with the term, it's just not one I use" - and feels uncomfortable with political labels. Class envy is a mystery to him; he sees no point in raising taxes for the super rich, because, he says, it wouldn't raise much revenue. "I'm not offended if someone earns large sums of money. Is it fair or not? It's just a fact of life." Asked to define his politics, he offers, "Pragmatic. I passionately believe in living in a fair country, and treating people properly, with proper respect and fairness."

Until the past year, Darling has never really had to fight. "For 10 years," he acknowledges, "as a minister, by and large I had a charmed life. I was sorting out problems rather than being landed with them." For the first time he is now facing an effective opposition - and the possibility of failure. The intriguing question will be whether he can survive, without the old political fuel of ideology or ego to drive him.

After narrowly avoiding being shut down by the judiciary for undermining the secular freedoms guaranteed by the constitution, the ruling Islamic party in Turkey, the AKP, has become extremely nervous of introducing any legislation that appears to advance the religious agenda. A protection of youth bill that contained anti-porn measures was hastily dumped after an outcry from secular forces.

In the context of the debates on pornography that take place in the UK, it seemed odd that the Turkish government had to stake its claim of being secular by adopting a libertarian position on pornography. Here, the debate is sharply divided between libertarians, who argue that pornography is the business of consenting adults, and not that of the state, and feminists, who oppose pornography on the grounds that it degrades women.

The law might seem an attractive tool in the fight against pornography because it signals what is unacceptable to society. Of course, British feminists recognise that the banning of pornography can be problematical, not merely because the dividing line between pornography and erotica is so fluid, but because it vests too much power in the state. Historically, such legislation has been used more broadly than intended to crack down on any sexually explicit material, often lesbian and gay material, without regard to whether it is exploitative. It is because of the dangers posed by a powerful state that Turkish feminists, whose views have so far gone unreported, are opposed to the bill.

Meltem Arikan, a Turkish writer and feminist, felt the heavy hand of the state when her book, Don't Hurt My Flesh, based on interviews with children who had experienced incest and abuse at home, was banned in 2004 under legislation designed to protect children from pornography. She had to defend the book in court before the ban was lifted. She believes that the protection of youth bill should have been called the policing of youth bill, because its provisions are designed to monitor and restrict the movements of young people. The bill proposed, for instance, that unaccompanied under-18s should not be allowed into restaurants after 10pm; true protection of young people would require the government to take steps towards prevention of abuse within the family. As far as the religious establishment is concerned, the family is sacrosanct, and any investigation into incest is out of bounds. Arikan suspects:

The government wants to use the protection of youth as an excuse to attack secularism, which was established in Turkey around 80 years ago. Therefore, feminists of Turkey, who are aware of the secret purpose of the government, are against the law.

Meanwhile, new legislation in the UK, the Criminal Justice and Immigration Act 2008, makes it an offence to be in possession of images of extreme pornography. It remains to be seen whether there will be a consensus on what constitutes "extreme". And whether a more liberal state can be trusted to make judgments that protect women from degradation.

Given the different alignment of social and political forces here, the anti-porn campaign has made feminists uneasy bedfellows with the religious lobby, which opposes porn on grounds of morality. The feminist agenda is, of course, quite distinct. We need to carve out a space for women to express our sexuality, distinct from constructions of women's sexuality by exploitative industries such as porn or prostitution, or the controlling strictures of religion.

John Lennon's troubled adolescence is to be the subject of a film from the writer of Control and the artist Sam Taylor-Wood.

Matt Greenhalgh, who won a Bafta for his screenplay about the final years of Joy Division's Ian Curtis, is to focus his script on the lonely teenage years of the future Beatle, who was raised by his authoritarian aunt after being abandoned by his mother. In the film, titled Nowhere Boy, Lennon finds solace in his music, art and friendship with Paul McCartney.

Taylor-Wood, who will be making her feature debut on the project, will shoot on location in Liverpool in the area where Lennon grew up. Casting is said to be underway on the project, and the Daily Mail reports today that Kate Winslet is being encouraged to audition for the role of Lennon's mother, Julia.

"The women in John's early life truly shaped who he became," Taylor-Wood told the Hollywood Reporter. "And the strengths and weaknesses of their relationships are central to this film."

The feature is being financed by Ecosse Films, with the support of the Film Council. It's not the first film to focus on Lennon, who as part of the Beatles was the subject of 1994's Backbeat, which focused on the band's early career in Hamburg. There was also 1991's The Hours and the Times, a fictionalised account of what might have happened when Lennon and Beatles manager Brian Epstein took a holiday together in 1963. Lennon was played by Ian Hart on both occasions.

Last year's The Killing of John Lennon centred on the final hours of Lennon's life from the perspective of his murderer, Mark Chapman.

While not having directed a feature film before, Taylor-Wood has a history working with musicians. She has produced films based on the Pet Shop Boys' Somewhere concerts at the Savoy theatre in London and made a promotional video starring Robert Downey Jr for the 2001 Elton John single I Want Love.

Tonight was the Big Speech, the night we've all been waiting for, the night to which the talking heads have been feverishly alluding all week, with ominous predictions and loaded rhetoricals about whether Barack Obama can live up to the hype, and whether he will leave the stage a nominee from a fractured or a unified party. And, of course, whether one or both of the Clintons will rush the stage and declare Hillary Clinton Queen of the Universe.

It could happen.

I know – because the talking heads in America's Cable News Land have been telling me so all week.

Hours before the main event, I flip to MSNBC just in time to see a brazen bystander touch the holy grail of Chris Matthews's mad hair. Jealousy consumes me. It is the first time I've wished I were in Denver.

Inside Mile-High Stadium, we are treated to some music. Will.I.Am gives us a nice live rendition of Yes We Can, which is followed by some canned music as Sheryl Crow sets up shop. On comes Bowie's cover of The Beatles' Across the Universe. "Nothing's gonna change my world…." Does not compute. It's not only a poor choice for the Change candidate, but it also fucks with one of my most closely-held truths, which is that everything always needs more Bowie, any Bowie.

There's nothing going on. It's all about the wait – just filling time until the Big Speech.

Savannah in the Cheap Seats, aka Savannah Guthrie, interviews a guy in the nosebleed section who says he likes Obama because "I'm for people and Obama's for people." I would like to say something snide about how long we've all waited for a president who has the guts to be "for people," but then I remember the last eight years and consider that tomorrow is the anniversary of Hurricane Katrina… After ten minutes or so spent weeping in the foetal position, I unfold myself and refocus, discovering Virginia Governor Tim Kaine complaining about John McCain's seven houses. Hey, at least he doesn't have 55.

More filler. Am I really watching Pat Buchanan wearing shades and desk-dancing to Stevie Wonder? What planet am I on?

Over at Fox News, they're STILL talking about McCain. Sean Hannity complains grumpily that during the Big Speech, we're not going to hear that Obama will cavort with dictators and we're not going to hear that Obama will raise taxes and we're not going to hear how the surge has been a success and we're not going to hear how the economy is awesome. Pout. I hope someone is standing by to resuscitate Hannity when Obama fails to talk about how he's going to enslave White America.

Ugh, Dick Morris – snivelling cretin. Morris, Hannity, and Alan Colmes banter briefly about Obama's speech. Who needs to actually watch the speech when you've got Fox News to tell you what to think about it before it even happens? Morris is certain it will stink based on provided excerpts. (Rarely do you find such an outstanding specimen of man, who is both toe-sucker and oracle.) Coming up on Fox's coverage of the Democratic convention: More speculation about McCain's veep selection.

Meanwhile, back on MSNBC, Keith Olbermann and company are analysing the long camera shots showing the (truly impressively) crowded stadium. Olbermann frets that it will make Obama look "smaller than life rather than bigger than life." Gee, well, let's hope he gets a close-up or two!

How much are these people paid?

Joe Biden takes the stage. I think there may be more people in the stadium than in the entire state of Delaware. He's loving it. He ends his speech, Rat Pack-like, with "Love ya!" which I have to say I much prefer to "God Bless You." "Love ya!" has some real bada-bing.

Filler, filler. Now the gang at MSNBC are pouring over the speech excerpts, and, while they're doing a better job than the loathsome Morris, it's still painful. If Nora O'Donnell refers to the "optics of this event" one more time, I'll go on a killing spree. It's nonetheless an improvement on what's going down at Fox, where they're rehashing "the Jeremiah Wright scandal" and Brit Hume begrudgingly admits that Mile-High Stadium is "pretty full." It's full metal crazy over there.

Finally, at long last, the senior senator from Illinois, Dick Durbin, comes out to introduce Obama, and we are moments away from the Big Speech. Jitter. Durbin's followed by a bio piece about Obama and his family, which is very nice.

And then Obama comes out.

Cameras flash like frenzied lightning bugs and the crowd roars. The staging is amazing. It is truly worthy of the historic moment to which we're all bearing witness – this is an African-American man who has is accepting the nomination for the presidency by the Democratic party. Wow. I am without cynicism or snark. I am awed.

I listen to the speech.

* * *

It's over. Chris Matthews, being uncharacteristically generous, says it was the hard-fought primary against Hillary Clinton that gave Obama "the steel" to be able to make this brilliant speech and live up to the enormous expectations and the overwhelming venue; he is palpably jizzing in his pants over the entire spectacle. I leave him to his private moment and check in with Fox. Brit Hume continues to begrudge Obama his success, and nearly refers to the candidate as "Barack Obama," but quickly corrects himself to use Fox News in-house style: "Barack Hussein Obama."

Over at CNN, Anderson Cooper compulsively refers to everyone who liked the speech as having "drunk the Kool-Aid." GOP consultant Alex Castellanos looks vaguely nauseated. If I had to go up against Obama with McCain, I'd be looking ill myself. Cooper and Wolf Blitzer discuss the speech with Campbell Brown, Paul Begala, and some other nitwits. The segment should be called How to Talk About Race Without Talking About Race. They agree Obama was not too uppity, which is euphemised as eschewing rhetoric that was "too soaring," and compliment his ability to "throw a punch" at McCain while not looking like the wild-eyed Angry Black Man, which is euphemised as being "formidable."

Blitzer then promises to talk to Clinton supporters after the break and see if Obama managed to win them over. Insert ominous score here. When we come back, Jessica Yellin is standing with an adorable elderly woman dressed head to toe in pink. She tells Yellin she's now an Obama supporter. What won her over? He did.

"The end is what got me. You know, it's a dream and it's going to come true. We gotta work for it."

And thus does the media-created story arc of the Democratic Convention come to a tidy end. The dragon of disunity has been slain, and Obama rides off into the sunset on his unity pony.

Who, I've been told, is fixing to graze on the lush lawns at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.

Was it God or Mammon that led to the "no" vote in Ireland's referendum on the EU Lisbon reform treaty? The leader of the country's Catholics certainly seems to think Lisbon's rejection last June was down to the former ... or at least the fact that He wasn't around.

Cardinal Sean Brady this week presented the absence of God in a supposedly ever-increasingly secular Europe as a major factor in voters' disillusionment with the EU project. The cardinal used a speech at a summer school to suggest in the strongest possible terms that the EU was promoting anti-family, anti-life and anti-Christian decisions. He even went as far as to say that some normally Europhile Christian voters were prompted to vote "no" because they perceived the EU as hostile to religion.

The irony of the particular summer school Cardinal Brady chose to launch his broadside against European secularism appeared lost on him and many others this week. The venue was the Humbert summer school in Killala, County Mayo, which was named after the French revolutionary general who commanded a doomed military operation to end British rule in the late 18th century.

General Jean Joseph Amable Humbert emerged from the seizures of 1789 and the French revolution, a movement that was as fiercely anti-clerical as it was anti-monarchical. In the years running up to the general's invasion and attempted liberation of western Ireland, successive revolutionary regimes fought bloody battles against the power of the Catholic church. Those struggles produced the secular French constitution of today with its strict separation of church and state.

Ireland doesn't have a French-style constitution, which among other things bans the display of religious symbols in schools. Unlike France, the Irish Republic still maintains a special position in public life for the Roman Catholic faith: abortion remains banned, the tolling of the Angelus Bells (the Catholic call to prayer) still rings out at 6pm every night on the Irish public television broadcaster, the church controls the vast majority of schools in the state, where the crucifix and other religious images are common.

Even as late as 2001, just as Bertie Ahern's first administration was winding up and preparing for the general election, Irish ministers rushed through a law that gave the Catholic church immunity from paying compensation to the child victims of clerical sex abuse. Instead, the first Ahern government ensured that the Irish taxpayer would be picking up the tab (running into tens of millions) for the church's crimes. The EU has never threatened or sought to overturn any of the above.

None the less, hardline Irish Catholics have never forgiven Europe over what they regard as interference in the republic's affairs.

The battle lines with Brussels were drawn back in the early 1990s, when the Irish authorities attempted to prevent a 14-year-old rape victim pregnant by her attacker travelling to Britain for an abortion.

The cack-handed way the government handled the affair created headlines around the world, with Dublin accused of reintroducing internment on the island – this time for young girls. What became known as the "X case" was followed by a series of scandals that rocked the church hierarchy, ranging from paedophile priests to bishops fathering children and using the collection plate funds to cover up their tracks.

In Cardinal Brady's universe there is a simple black/white distinction between the good religious world and the very bad, nasty secular one. In his and the minds of other senior figures in the Irish Catholic church the historic crimes of the 20th century – the Holocaust, the gulags, the Great Leap Forwards, Year Zero – are merely the toxic by-product of European secularism. Of course, this ignores entirely the role of both Catholic and Protestant theology in the antisemitism preceding the Shoah or sectarian slaughter from the Balkans to Ulster.

None of the major Irish political parties in the early 21st century today seeks to portray themselves as the defenders of the faith of our fathers. Despite fire-proofing the church from costly legal actions, political careers are no longer destroyed (as they were in the past) over accusations that someone in public life is irreligious or Godless or gay.

Unlike in Northern Ireland, where politicians such as Iris Robinson, the first minister's wife, can label homosexuality an "abomination" which can be cured by psychiatry, no party seeks to exploit personal moral issues or pick on sexual or religious minorities.

Nor is there an appetite in an increasingly multi-faith society for Ireland to turn the clock back to the days when condoms were illegal and no one dared say boo to a Catholic bishop. The age of absolute reverence to Rome among Ireland's a la carte Catholics has passed.

Preamble Bom bom bom... For 16 years, England's one-day cricket has been soundtracked by the theme from Curb Your Enthusiasm: a deliciously cringeworthy and amusing combination of haplessness, delusion and Vince Wells. But now, from nowhere, England look as if they are building a genuinely decent one-day side, and they can wrap up the series with two to spare if they win at the Oval today.

Sure, there have been false dawns before, and South Africa's minds are halfway across the world. But England are ticking a helluva lot of the boxes on the One-Day Competency Test: snappy fielding, serious depth of batting, old-ball wickettakers, decisive captaincy, middle-overs aggressors. If they sort out the opening pair and find a way to get a spinner in, and if the new-ball pair reduce the number of off days on which they are so hittable, then we really will have something to shout about.

Certainly, they will never get a better chance to whitewash a decent team. South Africa invested so much in finally winning a Test series here that they cannot get themselves up again (imagine if England had had to play a one-day series 10 days after the 2005 Ashes. Presactly). The emotional comedown is just too great. Now they are without the one man who could rouse them from their slumber, Graeme Smith, as well. I'd be amazed if they won any more than one of these remaining three games, and I think 5-0 is the most likely outcome. (You can get odds of of 4-1 on it. If I was a betting man etc etc.)

Not that we'd sniff at 4-1. Amazingly, England have not beaten a decent (ie not including Bangladesh and Zimbabwe) side by a margin of more than one game in two-team ODI series since they thwacked Australia 3-0 in 1997. That was 17 series ago, so we can't just blame that statistic on the preponderance of triangular tournaments.

England are unchanged. And you'd bloody hope so too.

Mortis, Prior (wk), Shah, Pietersen, Flintoff, Collingwood, Patel, Wright, Broad, Harmison, Anderson.

South Africa bring in Hashim Amla for the injured Smith and Morne Morkel for Andre Nel, who is harshly dropped despite top-scoring the other day.

Gibbs, Amla, Kallis (c), de Villiers, Duminy, Boucher (wk), A Morkel, Botha, M Morkel, Steyn, Ntini.

South Africa have won the toss and will bowl first. Understandable enough, in view of what happened the other day and the fact that it's a bit funky overhead.

One of the few disappointments this summer has been Dale Steyn. We really thought England were, as Walter from the Big Lebowski might have said, entering a world of Steyn. A world of Steyn. But it hasn't happened. Obviously injury hasn't helped, but I hope before the series is out we see at one stump-busting burst, because when he is on one he is a remarkable sight.

Technical problems?

Today could be a farce. Our system isn't working properly. Just so you know.

Jonny Sultoon has that Friday Feeling. In his case, it's a feeling of hate "Much as everyone feels the need to applaud his achievements in the last match, does anyone really want the Mouth of Sauron back behind the stumps on a permanent basis, wittering on as only he can to anyone within earshot that he drives a Vauxhall Tigra? Good for you - have a gold star." Not even an exclamation mark to finish. That's some real anger.

The most important line of the week came, as it so often does, from Scyld Berry in the Sunday Telegraph. "[Kevin Pietersen's] captaincy will no doubt end in tears, for England captains always end in tears, because the job is unsustainable, and nothing is done to reduce the over-load. But with each week of his nascent captaincy, the promise grows that before the premature ending there will be some glorious moments." Amen to that. We have yet to see how he copes with hardship, something Vaughan did exceptionally well in his first spell, but Pietersen has been exceptional so far.

Links bit So here we have a fun page where you can dress yourself up as a 60s ruffian and the like; here we have an upcoming awards night that I might attend just in case the new (or old) Emmy The Great is there; here we have Booth's new book, the office copy of which I'm going to nick when nobody's looking; and here we have some exciting new music (listen to Devil's Trident).

Stop whatever you're doing and read this. Oh, you are reading this, good point. Well, make sure you really read it. On Sunday, accompanied by a shower of friends and OBOers, I'm going to run/walk/wheeze 13 miles for the Laurie Engel Fund, and we are still desperate for sponsorship and/or people to join the run.

There's a Justgiving page and a Facebook group. But most of all, there's a simply heartbreaking story behind it. It makes every stitch a cinch, every wheeze a breeze, and puts every single measly facet of our lives in their appropriate context.

And, finally, warmest thanks to all of you who have sponsored us so far: the generosity proves that, while OBOers are a humourless bunch who couldn't produce a rib-tickling email between them, their hearts are in the right place.

Technical update It's working, but slowly, so updates might be 15 minutes after each over. What do you mean that's the norm?

1st over: England 1-0 (Bell 1, Prior 0) When we pull back the curtains the first thing we do is look up. When we start a cricket game the first thing we do is look for swing. There is some for Steyn, but it comes slowly off the pitch and there's not much sign of bounce. Bell shoulders arms at four of the deliveries, and tucks the last one off his pads to get off the mark.

2nd over: England 1-0 (Bell 1, Prior 0) Bell has this rigidly defined role, to bat through for 120 not out, and as discussed a week ago it really is a nonsense in the modern game. On he plods, with all the time in the world to get his eye in: a maiden, and Bell's strike-rate is 8.33, although it's not fair to expect him to go that fast all the time. No sign of pace in this pitch, although people still expect any at the Oval I don't know. It hasn't had any for over a decade.

In football, incidentally, Everton have agreed to sign Louis Saha subject to medical. Which is a bit like saying Scarlett Johansson has agreed to marry me, subject to meeting me.

3rd over: England 10-0 (Bell 9, Prior 0) That's what Bell can do. Steyn overpitches only a fraction and Bell drives him sumptuously down the ground for four. The next ball is short, lollops it nicely and is swivel-pulled for four more. Bell has the shots to be our Tendulkar/Mark Waugh at the top of the order. What was it En Vogue said about freeing your mind?

"Morning Rob," says Luke Dealtry. "Slightly worried about your use of the word 'Presactly'- hoping you're not going to go down the route of that heinous David Lynch Nissan advert and start spouting such
linguistic aberrations as 'Spafe', 'Modro' and the unutterable 'Spig'." I'm not that loathtidious.

4th over: England 27-0 (Bell 9, Prior 14) An over of the highest farce, missing only a bit of Benny Hill. It starts when Prior makes it three fours in as many balls when he creams Ntini's first delivery through extra-cover. The reply is a preposterous jaffa, a kicking leg-cutter that is even harder to play because of the wide angle. The next ball is the same, and seems to take the edge on the way through to Boucher. Ntini celebrates, Mike Atherton shouts "gone", but Kent legend Nigel Llong, the rich man's Gower in his pomp, says no. Replays show it's an outstanding decision, as it flicked the thigh pad.

The next ball is a no-ball, so a free hit. From that free hit, which is sliced over the slips for four by Prior, it's another no-ball. Then he bowls a wide, and from the next ball - still a free hit; keep up with me now - Prior gets his back leg out of the way and smears it over long-on for a regal six.

5th over: England 31-0 (Bell 13, Prior 14) It has, as Athers points out, been an odd morning: South Africa have bowled a fair few jaffas but enough garbage for England to tick along. There's four more, tucked off the pads by Bell off Steyn.

"South London is a steamy sauna today," says Gary Naylor, whipping off his clothes in front of some startled grannies, "and ideal for swing. Last night, Sky were making a big play of The Oval being a fast-scoring ground, but omitted to point out that it is also a wicket-taking ground for new ball bowlers. The long-suffering Surrey membership have seen a few 21-4 scoreboards this season. A 75-ball fifty from Belly Boy would be handy right now."

6th over: England 35-0 (Bell 13, Prior 18) A more sober over from Ntini, although it could hardly fail to be, but there's four more to Prior, crashed with real authority through the covers off the back foot. By golly he can look a good player.

I just used the word golly, didn't I?

"England have won the Ashes, subject to playing them?" offers Mike Holland.

7th over: England 46-0 (Bell 24, Prior 18) Lovely from Bell, who flicks Steyn lazily over square leg for four. Then he goes again, this time over midwicket. Two quite exquisite strokes. This is the thing with Bell: he absolutely has the game to open in one-day cricket; he just needs to step on it a bit. He's doing it today and this is the result: 24 from 25 balls.

"Two overs in and you're ALREADY having a go at Bell....... give it a rest!" says Rob Smith. "Having just hit a couple of cracking boundaries, is it time to reconsider? And have you thought that maybe he's batting to the orders of the management or captain?" I would have thought the phrase 'rigidly defined role' suggested that. Next!

8th over: England 59-0 (Bell 36, Prior 18) South Africa are haemorrhaging runs the noo, by fair means or foul. In that over Bell edges Ntini twice for four: once low, but once right in the gap between Boucher and Kallis, who was at about second slip. Bell salts the wound with a withering pull stroke for four more next ball. He is playing beautifully today.

In other news, Barney Ronay slipped into the special Small Talk underpants last week and went to meet Sourav Ganguly. Click here to find out how they bonded and whether it was a fully-fledged bromance.

9th over: England 63-0 (Bell 36, Prior 22) Morne Morkel replaces Steyn (4-0-25-0), but the boundaries continue to come: Prior has a gentle little walk down the track and times Morkel square on the off side. Morkel responds by beating Prior. They must have gone past the outside edge at least 10 times this morning. I always get excited when I can type the words "curate's" and "egg", and they certainly apply this morning.

Our warmest thanks to Hong King Centaurs Cricket Club, not only for being called Hong Kong Centaurs Cricket Club but also for a particularly generous donation ahead of Sunday's run.

10th over: England 77-0 (Bell 50, Prior 22) Well played Ian Bell. This has been a gem of an innings. He goes to fifty from 36 balls with 464 off consecutive deliveries from Ntini. The first was blitzed through extra-cover on the up, the second driven gloriously over long-off, and the third cut behind point. Brilliant stuff, and England have taken 76 from the last eight overs.

Here's Sam Walker. "Typical England: just as the world starts predicting the demise of 50-over cricket, we finally look like a team who can compete in the longer format!" Fair point, that, even if the exclamation mark wasn't strictly necessary. Understated jauntiness is so much more rewarding. Anyway, I'm great with a Rubik's Cube and can quote entire episodes of the Young Ones in the pub, but what good's that? It's all Peep Show and strap-ons these days.

11th over: England 83-0 (Bell 50, Prior 27) An absolute brute from Morkel follows Prior, takes the glove and loops over the slips for four. England are riding their luck, for sure, but they're riding it with vigour, shouting 'yeeha!' and 'giddy up buttercup!' at every opportunity.

Anyone out there? It's all a bit cricket. Come on, this is great stuff! Oh, here's one. "Re: 3rd over, 'presactly' and Luke Dealtry," says Tom Burford-Taylor IV. "May I offer you my deepest confibularities for reminding me of a fantastic episode of Blackadder III."

12th over: England 89-0 (Bell 52, Prior 31) Albie Morkel - what sort of a name is that for a human being - comes on for Ntini (5-1-47-0), and Prior edges an attempted yorker to third man for a couple before working one through midwicket for two more. If England carry on at this rate, they'll get 371. It's all rather good, this.

I just used the phrase 'rather good', didn't I?

"Rob Smyth has completed his 13-mile run," says Tom Hopkins, "subject to being carried for the last 12 miles?" You should see some of the other chancers who are doing it.

13th over: England 96-0 (Bell 59, Prior 31) Botham asks what a good score would be. This is an important point because sometimes England's minds aren't free enough. From here Australia would be looking for maybe 360; you suspect England will have their sights on 300.

Shots like that will help: Bell drives Morkel on the up through mid-off for another delicious boundary. Talking of which, here's Richard Marsden. "Over 2: 'Bell's strike-rate is 8.33, although it's not fair to expect him to go that fast all the time.' Would you like chips, new potatoes or salad with your words, sir?" I'll have a beer.

14th over: England 97-0 (Bell 60, Prior 31) A tight over Morkel (Albie), and in his haste to get a run Matt Prior is almost run out by de Villiers at backward point.

"Without looking, doesn't Tom Burford-Taylor IV mean 'contrafibularities'?" says James Galea. "Apologies for the pericombobulation."

15th over: England 99-0 (Bell 62, Prior 31) Bit of luck for Bell. He backed away, Morkel (Morne) followed him, and Bell inside-edged to fine leg for a couple. The two brothers have put the brakes on a bit, as South Africa desperately needed them to.

IMPORTANT PUBLIC SERVICE ANNOUNCEMENT FROM GORDON PITTENDRIGH "Hello. I have a bad hangover. Thanks."

WICKET! England 101-1 (Prior c Gibbs b A Morkel 33) Bah and balls. Prior tries to pull Albie Morkel, but it's on him too quickly and it loops into the covers, where Gibbs takes a sprawling catch. The frequency with which Prior gets out in the 30s in a one-dayer is starting to rival Ramprakash's spooky series of twentysomethings in his debut Test series in 1991.

16th over: England 109-1 (Bell 62, Shah 1) A bouncer from Albie Morkel flies over Boucher's head for five wides. Contrary to what I said earlier, this pitch does have a bit in it, and England's battery of basketball players should enjoy bowling on it. "Re: the other chancers in over 12," begins Tom Hopkins. "You're not wrong. Have you met Dave Hopkins yet? I'm not sure he could make 13 miles in a car."

17th over: England 109-1 (Bell 62, Shah 1) Bell is suddenly becalmed: at one stage he had 58 from 43 deliveries and now, after that maiden, he has 62 from 63. You do the match. The Morkels have really pulled this back: they have combined figures of one for 36 from eight. Weren't they Ben Hollioake's figures on his ODI debut, only without the wicket?

Another link, the last one I promise: this one's to a podcast on which I get pretty much everything except my name wrong.

18th over: England 116-1 (Bell 63, Shah 6) Shah leans into a really fibrous cover-drive off Albie Morkel, sending it skimming to the fence. I'm still not convinced about Shah at No3, but time will tell. There aren't too many alternatives I suppose. I'd like to see Bopara there personally. It's all mememe round here.

"Albie really isn't a name for a human being," says Will Burchell. "As every Flight of the Conchords fan (which really should be everybody by now) knows, Albie is a name for a racist dragon."

19th over: England 120-1 (Bell 65, Shah 7) Maybe we're entering an age of the change bowler in one-dayers: England's most important two are pitch-hitters, as are South Africa's. They have done very well here, although there's a front-foot no-ball from Morne Morkel in that over, and thus a free hit. Shah has a huge roundhouse swing at a short one and misses it. England have taken only 24 from the last six overs, and South Africa will be happy with that given that we're in Powerplay territory.

"If England score a massive total, I can see South Africa having a better chance of winning than if they only score 250ish," says Andy Bradshaw. "Mainly because the Saffers have nothing to lose but giving it the long handle and hoping for the best." It sounds absurd, but I know what you mean - the same thing as happened in that amazing match 872-run ODI against the Aussies at Jo'burg. So I fully expect to see Flintoff and co turn down singles once we reach 250.

20th over: England 126-1 (Bell 66, Shah 11) Ah ya. Albie Morkel digs it in and Shah plays the most regal pull stroke, high over midwicket for four. When Shah is playing well he treats bowlers with the most thrilling contempt.

"Honestly, Rob - you'd have to go back a whole year and two days to
find the last time that Prior got out for 30-something in an ODI," says Scott Collier. Ah, well fair enough. But you know what I mean: getting out when set to a limp stroke.

21st over: England 128-1 (Bell 67, Shah 12) An important time in the game, this, as the spinner Botha comes on. Important in particular for Bell, who needs to take at least three singles from every four balls. For now it's Shah for most of the over, and he permits himself a look at Botha. Two from the over.

"Never mind old Blackadder scripts: Clare Davies, Lee Calvert and I invented a few words at the Cricket Lexicon," says Gary Naylor. "This one seems about right for the moment: Bell (v) - To maintain oneself in a game, but no more. Usage - 'When holding middle pair on the flop, a good Texas Hold'em player doesn't raise or fold, but just bells until the turn card is revealed.' 360 would be a full house; 300 just a two pair."

22nd over: England 132-1 (Bell 69, Shah 14) Steyn is back, at the opposite end from where he bowled this morning. England have definitely dropped down a gear, which is completely unnecessary when you have so many batsmen to come. Four singles from the over.

Andrew Brittain is a funny man. A really, really funny man. "When/if Bell is out why don't you say: 'Well we've seen the innings of Bell begin and now we've seen the innings of Bell end'. Use it if you want. I give it to you free of charge."

23rd over: England 138-1 (Bell 72, Shah 17) Shah's single takes him to 1000 in ODIs. When he charmed us all with his intrepid performances in his debut series in 2001, you'd have got long odds on it taking seven years for him to reach that little milestone. Anyway it's a good over for England, who do what all good teams do against modest spinners - get a run a ball with minimal risk.

"PLEASE CALL ME AND GET BACK TO MY EMAIL: 00226-70 64 24 10," demands Muhamadad Allauddin. Must be another booty call.

24th over: England 143-1 (Bell 72, Shah 22) Another wonderfully dismissive stroke from Shah, pulling Steyn to the fence at midwicket. Then he agrees to a ludicrous single and, had de Villiers running in from backward point hit the stumps, Bell would have been long gone. That's just reminded of Long Gone by the Super Furries. Halcyon days.

Kristian Petterson has a steel toecap on his size 9s, and he wants to move it forcefully in the direction of my dusters. "Having now flogged the same gag twice, I was just wondering if you planned to use the word 'presactly' on any more occasions on August 29th?"

WICKET! England 143-2 (Bell LBW b Botha 73) South Africa are the ones celebrating but I reckon this is better news for England. Bell, beaten for pace and trapped in front on the back foot, has gone and Pietersen is in at pretty much the perfect time. Bell played stunningly well at the start but made only 15 from his last 34 deliveries.

25th over: England 146-2 (Shah 23, Pietersen 2) I may have the individual scores wrong. So sue me!

"If he became a lifeguard you could get saved by the Bell," says Dave Whittam. "I'm so sorry." Not nearly as sorry as your mother must be.

WICKET! England 146-3 (Shah b Kallis 23) Kallis brings himself on, presumably to bowl at his bunny Pietersen, but in fact he cleans up Shah first ball. Shah pushed forward at a length ball but could only inside-edge it back onto timber. Actually, in fairness to Kallis, it was a decent delivery, seaming in enough to take the inside edge.

26th over: England 150-3 (Pietersen 1, Flintoff 4) Flintoff gets off the mark with a sublime shot, pinging Kallis through extra-cover for four. As Atherton points out, it's good when he starts an innings by timing the ball, as he did there, rather than trying to belabour it.

27th over: England 153-3 (Pietersen 3, Flintoff 5) Serene stuff in that over, as tends to be the case after two quick wickets. The key here is that Pietersen takes as much of Botha as possible, because he could milk a spinner for 90 runs per 100 balls in his sleep. In that over he takes two from two balls against Botha, and Flintoff one from four. You do the math.

WICKET! England 155-4 (Pietersen LBW b Kallis 5) Kallis really does have Pietersen on a plate. Pietersen tried to whip a big off-cutter through midwicket, missed and was pinned in front. It was hitting, no doubt about that, but it was marginal as to whether he was hit outside the line. I suspect he was hit outside the line. Anyway, Nigel Llong gave it - it certainly looked out live - and Kallis is producing a captain's bowling performance, as nobody ever says because captains are so rarely bowlers.

28th over: England 157-4 (Flintoff 5, Collingwood 2) Collingwood, back from his ban, jabs his first ball through midwicket for two. Kallis has figures of 2-0-8-2.

29th over: England 158-4 (Flintoff 6, Collingwood 2) Botha will look to hustle through overs for three or four a pop now, or even better: just one from that over to Flintoff. It's such a blow to lose Pietersen when Botha still has six overs in the bank.

"So... still think it was a good time for Belly Boy to get out?" says Chris Blunt, in a smug manner that in no way makes one wonder what rhyming slang might be used to give him an appropriate nickname.

I jest.

I just used the word 'one', didn't I?

30th over: England 160-4 (Flintoff 7, Collingwood 3) Flintoff always likes to play himself for 20 balls or so, and that's what's happening the noo. England's Manhattan is ski-sloping, if that's isn't the most absurd thing anyone has ever written, ever.

Anyone there? My inbox hasn't seen any hot action for ages.

31st over: England 165-4 (Flintoff 10, Collingwood 5) Flintoff, on the walk, manages to squeeze Botha past square-leg for a couple in an other that brings England an acceptable five.

Okay, okay, definitely the last link: this one is to Dileep Premachandran's
excellent blog on the Champions Trophy fall-out. Okay so I haven't read it as I'm doing this, but with Dileep it's a fair assumption.

32nd over: England 167-4 (Flintoff 10, Collingwood 8) More irritatingly effective fare from Kallis, possibly the most loathed great player of all time (a bit harshly, I feel). Three from it; not two, as previously advertised.

"Does anyone out there know of an iPhone application for OBO coverage?" asks Alwyn Frank. "It would make my life a lot easier." I'm out there - as the crotchless leather chaps/dungarees combo I'm sporting today would confirm - but I have no idea. You rich people crease me up. I'm still trying to get it on the Spectrum.

33rd over: England 172-4 (Flintoff 12, Collingwood 10) This is good from Botha, statistically anyway. I'm quite useless at appraising modest spinners - Patel and Mike Yardy, for example, look to me like men who should be going for 90 a pop - but it's hard to argue with what he's done so far: 7-0-24-1. The Hawkeye graphic shows that his off-stump line is very, very consistent.

34th over: England 181-4 (Flintoff 17, Collingwood 14) Flintoff drives Kallis over mid-on for four, the first since the 26th over. Collingwood adds another, charging Kallis and dumping him disdainfully over midwicket. Top shot.

"I bought a new bat yesterday," says Alan White, drawing at 0% of readers to the edge of their seat, "...and without wishing to give free sponsorship, I thought it was the one used by Marcus Trescothick, my favourite player. Imagine my horror when I discovered it was actually endorsed on the maker's website by, er, Steve Harmison. Oh, and Ryan Sidebottom apparently. Do any of your readers have a bat with a less impressive 'face'?" Insert your own joke here.

WICKET! England 182-5 (Collingwood c Boucher b Botha 14) The tamest of dismissals. Collingwood pushed almost absent-mindedly at a delivery on leg stump, and it plopped onto the pad and up in the air for Boucher to take a simple catch. Collingwood looked cheesed off, and replays weren't conclusive as to whether he hit it, but there were two noises and it just felt out.

That's the bad news. The good news is that Samit Patel is about to play his first innings for England. This boy can bat, I'm here to tell you.

35th over: England 184-5 (Flintoff 18, Patel 1) Gregg Roughley, my designated gimp for the day, has just served the most ridiculously strong cup of coffee, so if I start talking utter nonsense (insert your own etc) you know who to blame.

36th over: England 187-5 (Flintoff 20, Patel 2) Ntini is back with the harder replacement ball, but I didn't see that over as I trying to put together a link to our county blog, which I have failed to do as I am an html-illiterate gugootz. Anyway, you can get it here: http://blogs.theguardian.com/sport/2008/08/29/county_cricket_live_53.html. Sorry.

37th over: England 196-5 (Flintoff 26, Patel 4) Flintoff turns a modest over into a good one by carting a full toss from Botha through wide mid-on for four. Eight from the over.

In other news, here's a remarkable little burst of vitriol for a Friday afternoon from Ian Palmer. "Collingwood fails again because his place is not on the line. SURPRISE SURPRISE."

38th over: England 202-5 (Flintoff 32, Patel 5) Four more to Flintoff, who charges Ntini and flays him through the covers. Despite that little mid-innings wobble, England are still in a good position and should get around 280 here.

39th over: England 207-5 (Flintoff 34, Patel 6) Morne Morkel is back and nearly puts Patel on his appreciable backside with a very good bouncer. "In response to Alan White, my bat is made by a company that sponsors Cheshire CCC and the Spanish national side," says Craig Woodhouse. "That's surely less impressive?"

40th over: England 217-5 (Flintoff 38, Patel 13) Stale Steyn (6-0-34-0) replaces Ntini (7-1-57-0), and Flintoff is lucky to get away with a clunked pull that just looped safely over midwicket for two. Then Patel plays a charming, wristy pull behind square for four, his first boundary in international cricket. Ten from the over.

41st over: England 220-5 (Flintoff 39, Patel 14) Morkel beats Flintoff for pace, thudding a bouncer into his helmet. A number of batsmen have been done for pace on the bouncer today, which will bode well for when England bowl. Flintoff is definitely rattled, and is walking across with a fuzzy head as the physio treats him with, er, Red Bull. He'll be fine. He's a big boy.

Someone send me an email. Please.

42nd over: England 227-5 (Flintoff 44, Patel 16) Patel has looked fine so far, taking as many singles as possible in preparation for the final assault. He's very fidgety about the crease, although that did Michael Slater no harm.

Back at the ranch, Flintoff times Steyn over de Villiers at backward point for four. It's hard not to get very excited about the way he's batting in this series. Very excited.

Apparently some overs are missing: if so, sorry for that and wotnot. I am typing of all them, but we are having genuine rather than euphemistic technical problems today.

"Sic Transit Gloria: England's Innings," says Alex Netherton, who may or may not have spent the last 44 days in a darkened room watching Rushmore on loop.

43rd over: England 238-5 (Flintoff 49, Patel 22) Kallis replaces Steyn, and Patel inside-edges his first ball to fine leg for four. Whoop whoop! A single brings up the fifty partnership at more than a run a ball - that's an excellent effort, given that there had to be an element of consolidation in their work. Flintoff celebrates by charging Kallis and thwacking a short one behind backward point for four.

"My bat has a very impressive face," says Tom Paternoster. "Unfortunately the edges are all battered. Sorry." You come to my door and you offer me this?

44th over: England 246-5 (Flintoff 52, Patel 28) Consecutive fifties for Flintoff. This one has been a nice, controlled effort, from 56 balls and with six fours. Platforms don't come much better.

From the next ball Patel gives himself room and belabours Ntini through mid-off for four. Shot! Eight from the over, and England should be looking for 300 now.

"I'd be interested to know whether or not you feel that Pietersen's remarkably camp walk/mince has become any more exaggerated since his elevation to Captaincy," says Matthew Swann. "It can surely only be a matter of time before he skips onto the field a la Larry Grayson." That wouldn't be the only Grayson-related farce seen in an England cricket match this century, eh?

45th over: England 253-5 (Flintoff 57, Patel 31) Flintoff screams Kallis down the ground for four in another decent over for England: nine from it. But, as Gary Naylor points out, India chased over 300 here last year so assumptions of hegemony are dangerous.

WICKET! England 256-6 (Patel b Ntini 31) The end of an encouraging little innings from Patel, who gave himself room and lost his off stump.

46th over: England 258-6 (Flintoff 59, Wright 1) Luke Wright could do with a few runs to prove that he deserves his place above Mascarenhas.

Anyway, here's Chris Milner. "In Paul Doyle's MBM t'other day the first 25 minutes were missed due to an 'almighty technicological palaver'. Given the regularity of these incidents, i'm wondering if GU staff have some kind of dare/betting scheme going on to see who can leave out the most or have the biggest gap in MBM/OBO reports. How far can it go? How long will it be before you claim the GU coputers to have become 'self-aware' and have taken over the office, before going outside for a cig for the entire duration of the match?" Funnily enough I've never had technical problems before: I was just suffering from booze and made them up. That doesn't happen anymore. But they changed the system recently and I believe there have been a few teething problems. Either that or everyone here is a raging alcoholic, each hiding hipflasks under the desk and enjoying a quick snort every time they tie their shoelaces. I'll let you decide.

47th over: England 263-6 (Flintoff 61, Wright 4) Luke Wright slugs Morkel not far over midwicket for a couple. I think Wright, like the excellent Stewart Downing, gets undeserved criticism because of his manager's background.

"Are you going to be doing an OBO for the run on Sunday?" says Lynn Bashforth. "Or an Ouch By Ouch as Richard O'Hagan suggests." Not all of us have a Blackberry, darling. Can you get wi-fi on a Spectrum?

48th over: England 275-6 (Flintoff 72, Wright 5) Flintoff slams Steyn's first ball square on the off side for four. Steyn replies well, conceding only two runs from the next four balls, but Flintoff finishes the over in style by carting a slower ball over midwicket for six.

"Having not seen much of Samit Patel, is there enough encouragement from his batting and bowling so far to suggest he might be more than just a Michael Yardy clone?" asks Kevin Wilson. "The halcyon days of Yardy and Dalrymple in the same team!" I'd say his bowling is no better, but as batsmen they're incomparable. Patel has a lot of class. We didn't really see it today, except for that pull, as he just played sensibly in the situation. The worry is whether he'd good enough to be the main spinner. I doubt it, but then that shouldn't be his role: he's a batsman who bowls.

49th over: England 291-6 (Flintoff 76, Wright 15) Sixteen from the over, and England still have a chance of reaching 300. It starts with a brilliant shot from Luke Wright. Having made room, he stretched way outside off stump to slash a full toss from Morne Morkel over the off side, and got four with the aid of some blundering in the field from Ntini. Then, after a wide, Wright spanks a short ball over midwicket for four more.

After he takes a single, Flintoff joins in with a splendid stroke. He walked across his stumps, so Morkel bounced him. Instead of doing what Brian Close would have done - chested it down like a centre back - Flintoff simply swiveled to dump the ball over short fine leg for a one-bounce four.

WICKET! England 295-7 (Wright c Gibbs b Steyn 17) Wright clunks the penultimate ball to midwicket, and England need six off the last ball to reach 300.

50th over: England 296-7 (Flintoff 78, Broad 0) Sky miss the final ball, because of an advert about strap ons or some such. Anyway, it's a leg bye and that makes it a good final over for South Africa: five from it. Flintoff ends unbeaten on 78, from 77 balls. It was a really good, mature knock, especially as a flurry of wickets fell near the start of his innings.

England will be pretty happy with their work, particularly as things were looking iffy at 182 for five in the 35th. I'd say the game is about 60/40 in their favour. Join me in half an hour to find out.

See you in a bit, yeah?

1st over: South Africa 1-0 (target: 297; Amla 1, Gibbs 0) Here we go. Amla is playing only his fourth ODI - the others were against Bangladesh - and opening for the first time.

Already you can hear Prior screaming like a fanzine seller: "Jimmy Anderson's day today - come on boys!" Well if Anderson wasn't pumped before, he surely will be now. It's a decent first over, with a bit of swing and one that beat Gibbs's outside edge; one from it.

Cook is on for Flintoff, who was clearly shaken when Morkel pinned him with a bouncer. Apparently he won't be off for long; he's just watching the end of Diagnosis: Murder.

2nd over: South Africa 2-0 (target: 297; Amla 2, Gibbs 0) A quiet start, this. Here, incidentally, is a
blog I wrote earlier on why England should have a fluid batting order. It's not very good, but if you read that'll stop you thinking about the mess your life has become for at least 30 seconds, so it's a good deal really.

"We're going to lose, aren't we?" asks Clare Davies. No, no we're not. "We" are going to win by 77 runs, and then "we" are going to go and get royally reduced on booze!

3rd over: South Africa 4-0 (target: 297; Amla 2, Gibbs 1) A lucky escape for Amla, who chipped Anderson towards mid-on, but the ball died just short of Harmison. This is a good start from England. Anderson in particular has dragged his length back to the short side of full, and they're struggling to get him away.

"After living here for five years, I've been granted residency from the Home Office," says Erik Pedersen, like it's a good thing. "To celebrate my newfound Englishness – or at the very least, the sort of pseudo-Britishness that means I'm no longer required to go through the Shifty Foreign Types queue at Heathrow – I've got tickets for Lord's on Sunday. As the day's meant to be Erik's Big Orgy of Englishness, I was wondering if there's anything in particular that I should do or see at Lord's to wring every last drop of Englishness out of proceedings. While we're at it, if there's anything outside of the cricket that I should be doing, that would also be appreciated." Hating yourself would be a big start.

4th over: South Africa 7-0 (target: 297; Amla 4, Gibbs 1)
Stuart Broad, who is fourth in the official ODI bowling rankings (above Murali and McCague), continues to Amla, who it's fair to say isn't the most natural one-day opener. Broad has a biggish shout for LBW but there was doubt on height and also whether it was sliding down. Just dribs and drabs so far. The body language of South Africa's openers reminds me of Nicolas Anelka's as he wandered up to the penalty area in Moscow on May 21.

5th over: South Africa 10-0 (target: 297; Amla 4, Gibbs 5) Three from that Anderson over, and so far South Africa haven't played a shot in ang- saying which, Amla fresh-airs a loose hook shot. In other, probably more important news, I've just opened my Lucozade Alert: Lemon Zing, and the mother has sprayed everywhere. Wah! My poor Lucozade Alert: Lemon Zing!

"Marmite sandwiches, pickled onion Monster Munch and Wagon Wheels,
washed down with warm - warm dammit - beer," offers Wayne Stubbs, in reference to over three.

6th over: South Africa 18-0 (target: 297; Amla 5, Gibbs 12) Next ball, Gibbs survives a brutally tight referral to the third umpire. He was quite casual when it came to getting his bat in and, after a direct hit from Patel, it was almost impossible to tell if he was in. It was a split-frame job and, while on balance you suspect he was out, it could not have been given with a clear conscience. Next ball, Gibbs creams Broad through the covers for the first boundary of the innings.

"Erik in the third over could try changing his surname from Pedersen to Pietersen," says Fraser Nock, who might consider a bit of moniker-alteration himself.

WICKET! South Africa 19-1 (Gibbs c Shah b Anderson 12) Gibbs has definitely gone this time. He was driven on to the back foot by Anderson and could only push it firmly to Shah at short cover. That's a really big wicket for England, because Gibbs is the only loose cannon in this top six.

7th over: South Africa 21-1 (target: 297; Amla 7, Kallis 1) England will cruise this. South Africa don't want to know.

8th over: South Africa 30-1 (target: 297; Amla 16, Kallis 1) Amla finally locates the boundary, fizzing a short one from Broad classily behind square on the off side. Then he goes across his stumps to rubber-wrist one to fine leg for four more. Really good shot.

"I agree with you about fluid batting," says Julian Bamford. "When skipper myself I liked Nos 4,5 & 6 padded up after the first wicket went down. Another country will 'invent' this idea and three years later we will start to use it."

9th over: South Africa 31-1 (target: 297; Amla 17, Kallis 1) This is all strangely subdued at the moment, although that will suit England. Just one from Anderson's over and the required rate is up to 6.5 now. Both bowlers have again hit 90mph, by the way.

10th over: South Africa 34-1 (target: 297; Amla 20, Kallis 1)
England haven't bowled especially well here - Broad in particular has been quite loose - but the South Africans' timing in particular is way off.

"Job done," says Jonny Sultoon. "Keep these two Tavare clones together at the crease and the final score will read 192-1 (Kallis 76*, Amla 91*). Definitely a case of 'dropped catches win matches'."

11th over: South Africa 35-1 (target: 297; Amla 21, Kallis 1) Anderson continues to Amla, WHO COULD LEARN A THING OR TWO ABOUT OPENING THE BATTING IN ONE-DAY CRICKET FROM IAN BELL, EH? For the most part it's more strokeless nonsense. Something will have to give soon, because the required rate is ticking up towards seven now. Amla has 21 from 38 balls, Kallis 1 from 12. Excellent stuff from Anderson, who has one for 11 from six.

"Surely," says Andy Bradshaw, "Eric should now be complaining about how the country's gone down the pan and how he is thinking about emigrating somewhere much better where the weather's good and young people are shot on sight."

12th over: South Africa 40-1 (target: 297; Amla 25, Kallis 2) Amla is going a long way across to Broad, and that enables him to work one through midwicket for three. But for the most part, South Africa's timing is absolutely shocking here. They look like one-legged men trying to play musical chairs. I'd be inclined to get Flintoff on now to really ram home this advantage.

13th over: South Africa 47-1 (target: 297; Amla 30, Kallis 3)
That's more like it from Amla, who gets a straighter, fuller delivery from Anderson and sends it spinning through midwicket for four.

"Hello Smyth," says Alison Rivett. "Erik should get into the 'Rnglish' 'spirit' at the cricket by whiling away the 45 minutes until the Oval bars open again by finishing off his warm Lambrini he's smuggled in. Well, that's what we're doing...". Lambrini. Lambrini.

14th over: South Africa 58-1 (target: 297; Amla 37, Kallis 3) Harmison replaces Broad, and almost gets Amla in his first over. Amla played a deliberate uppercut, but it bounced only a couple of yards from Jimmy Anderson, running round, before going for four. Then Amla gets four in more orthodox circumstances, driving Harmison pleasantly through the covers. Eleven from the over. Who invited this tool back into the team?

"Apart from the weather, Andy Bradshaw's vision of foreign shores (over 11) sounds a bit too much like Moss Side for my liking," honks Matthew Kilsby. Isn't the native tongue easier to understand overseas? HONK!

15th over: South Africa 67-1 (target: 297; Amla 46, Kallis 3) Suddenly the runs are flowing. Flintoff, on for Anderson, sees his first two balls disappear for four: the first an uppercut from Amla, the second a classy flick over square leg.

And yes, I did have the individual scores wrong earlier in the innings.

"Eric should probably start indulging in meaningless adoration of 80s celebrities," says Alex Netherton. "Hilarious." Not as funny as that Uncle Albert from Only Fools & Horses though? With the beard? Got a picture of him on my wall!

WICKET! South Africa 67-2 (Amla c Prior b Harmison 46) Amla goes. He was starting to play really well, but perhaps he got carried away because he had a big flail at Harmison. He didn't get hold of it, however, and it flew off the inside-edge for Prior to take a good, tumbling catch.

16th over: South Africa 67-2 (target: 297; Kallis 3, de Villiers 0) A wicket maiden for Harmison.

17th over: South Africa 70-2 (target: 297; Kallis 3, de Villiers 1) Phwoar, that's a peach. Flintoff gets a legcutter to lift past the outside edge of the new batsman de Villiers, and Pietersen brings in a slip as a result.

"Is there anything sweeter in cricket for the opposition than seeing Jacques 'must protect my average' Kallis at the crease?" asks Andy Bradshaw before, to save us the trouble, answering his own question. "I suppose Ian Bell coming out when England are 35 for two chasing 450." In a Twenty20 game. That's been reduced by rain.

18th over: South Africa 76-2 (target: 297; Kallis 9, de Villiers 6) Kallis is having a nightmare. It's the captain's logjam. He couldn't middle it with a tank, and inside edges Harmison for one.
